column4: For example, how am I supposed to know that the correct process is to leave the "headers" package?
You cannot derive that from seeing the grub entry.
but how do I know that the "headers" package is not the kernel?
And how do I know that the "image" package is the correct package to remove
headers != kernel, two different things
You just need to remove the linus-image-blahblahblah package via Synaptic for the kernels you want to remove.
It is as un-dangerous as it can be. Much better than trying to do it manually.
Just don't remove the latest one or  whichever one you want to use.
It can't eally get any more simple or foolproof. If you are messing with kernels, it is assumed you have a reason to do so, and thus have an idea of what you are doing.
it is quite reversible.
I have reason to because I want to make my boot menu clear. Otherwise I do not want to know anything about the Kernel
OK then. Just remove all the kernels aside from the one you are using.
sounds like you're good then. ;)
